XsOutputMode m_outputMode

uint16_t m_period
 The period between updates in 115200Hz intervals.
 
uint16_t m_skip
 The skip factor wrt m_period.
 

Detailed Description

Contains the output configuration of a device.

Remarks
Skipfactor

The skip factor can be used to achieve lower update rates than the sample rate. For most update rates setUpdateRate will successfully come up with a period and skip factor that results in the correct sample rate with output skip factor. In some cases the resulting values may not be desirable. When this happens, use this function in combination with setPeriod or setUpdateRate.

The skip factor determines the update rate relative to the actual sample rate as

For example, to achieve an output rate of 25 Hz, one could write

XsDeviceMode mode;
mode.setUpdateRate(25);

or more explicitly:

XsDeviceMode mode;
mode.setUpdateRate(100);
mode.setSkipFactor(3);
Note
MT Mk4 devices are better configured using XsOutputConfiguration, this object is supplied for legacy support only.

double XsDeviceMode::sampleRate ( void  ) const
inline

Get the sample rate in Hz.

The sample rate is the frequency at which the MT internally queries the IMUs. It can be much higher than the update rate depending on the type of device and filter requirements.

Returns
The sample rate in Hz
See also
setSkipFactor(int)
m_skipFactor, period()
updateRate()

void XsDeviceMode::setUpdateRate ( int  rate)
inline

Set the update rate to the given rate.

The update rate is internally expressed as a period and a skip factor. This may cause the actual update rate to differ up to 2Hz from the value set.

Parameters
rateThe update rate to set
See also
updateRate(), sampleRate(), period(), m_skipFactor, setPeriod(uint16_t), setSkipFactor(uint16_t)

uint16_t XsDeviceMode::updateRate ( void  ) const
inline

Get the update rate in Hz.

The update rate is the frequency at which data is output by the sensor. This frequency is a result of sampleRate and skipFactor.

Returns
The current update rate
See also
setUpdateRate(int)
m_skipFactor, period()
